hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the linked list. Each segment of the list is separated by a node with a value of 0. Your task is to sum the values of the nodes between each pair of 0s.
Consider how you will traverse the linked list. You can use a pointer to iterate through the nodes. Remember, you need to skip the 0s while summing the values of the nodes in between.
Think about how you will store the sums of the segments. You could use a temporary variable to accumulate the sum as you traverse through the nodes, resetting it each time you encounter a 0.
When you reach a 0, check if your temporary sum is greater than 0 before you reset it. This ensures you only create a new node if there was a sum to add.
You will need a way to build the new linked list with the summed values. Consider initializing a new head for the result list and using a pointer to keep track of where to add new nodes.
Make sure to handle the end of the list correctly. After the last segment of nodes, you will need to ensure you finalize the last sum before returning the new list.
Think about edge cases, such as when the segments between 0s have only one node. Ensure your logic correctly sums and creates a node for such cases.
As you build the new list, remember to link the nodes correctly. Each new node should point to the next node in the new list until you reach the end.
Consider the constraints given in the problem. You know there will always be at least three nodes, and the values will be between 0 and 1000. This can help simplify your logic.
Finally, ensure that your function returns the head of the newly created linked list. You can return the head of the new list you built after processing the original list.

questionNotes: The linked list starts and ends with a node having value 0.
There are no two consecutive nodes with value 0.
You must return the head of the modified linked list without any 0s.
The number of nodes in the list is between 3 and 200,000.
